title: Stanford CS230 | Autumn 2025 | Lecture 1: Introduction to Deep Learning
description:
For more information about Stanfordâ€™s Artificial Intelligence professional and graduate programs, visit: https://stanford.io/ai

September 23, 2025
This lecture covers:
1. Class introduction
2. Examples of deep learning projects
3. Course details

To learn more about enrolling in this course, visit: https://online.stanford.edu/courses/cs230-deep-learning

To follow along with the course schedule and syllabus, visit: https://cs230.stanford.edu/syllabus/

More lectures will be published regularly. 
View the playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLoROMvodv4rNRRGdS0rBbXOUGA0wjdh1X

Andrew Ng
Founder of DeepLearning.AI
Adjunct Professor, Stanford Universityâ€™s Computer Science Department

Kian Katanforoosh
CEO and Founder of Workera
Adjunct Lecturer, Stanford Universityâ€™s Computer Science Department

comments.author: @enisten
comments.content: 3:54 How can performance keep getting better and better if it represents accuracy? The most it can be is 100%. Does he mean traditional machine learning models plateaued at unacceptably low rates of accuracy, while DNNs can reach 100% (i.e., perfection) with enough data? Also, doesn't this graph gloss over the possibility of overfitting for larger DNNs? I am assuming the y axis represents accuracy on test sets.

comments.author: @amh228
comments.content: i found some of these sentiments deeply disturbing, though coming from an all time great!! You only hire people who use code generators?? Especially after noting the damage and potential harm that can come from writing code that we don't fully understand, generated by pattern-producers that err on average 20% of the time.. I think a security nightmare is incoming if this is how other employers think. Truly creative or important work will never be produced by "making more faster", we should tread very carefully here. Respectfully disagree with parts of this beautiful lecture.

comments.author: @TheSummerLab1
comments.content:
47:50 
AI is still not good at WebGPU and WebGL - basically any 3D web programming. Lack of training data is the reason. One of the interesting results is that if people stop coding, AI will enter into a self reinforcing loop - where it is no more guided by relevance, and in many cases have a negative feedback loop of hallucination if original content is not produced.

replies.author: @dixon1e
replies.content:
At the end of the first time he gave his original machine learning class online, we all showered him with such affection that he (I believe) cried (just a bit) at the last lecture thanking us for the experience. We were blown away by how easy he made it to learn something so complex.

A fundamental part of why we do what we do in Computer Science and the wider world involves empathy. And this is far more uncommon than it should be. That puts him in a far different, and higher league. 

Well done, Andrew Ng.
